title: fix wrong test description and failure message
Created a registry for ActiveSupport::Subscriber queues
body:
I'm limiting the number of thread locals that come from each new subscriber. Instead of creating a new thread local for each queue, there is only a single thread local that is created which stores all the queues.

It follows the pattern of the ``ActiveSupport::PerThreadRegistry`` module.

title: Added tests for if condition in Active Model callbacks
Removing tests for deprecated options in active support.
body:
The two tests I'm removing here are actually duplicates of ``test_render_file``. The reason they are duplicates is historical: the options that these two tests were supposed to check were deprecated, and the person who deprecated these options forgot to remove the test.

The ``use_full_path`` option was removed in 3b3790a which stops ``test_render_file_not_using_full_path`` from being useful. Also, passing the template handler to render was deprecated in 43d27e9, which stops ``test_render_file_without_specific_extension`` from being useful.

title: fix typos
body: fix some typos

title: Add inflections for goose, geese, and deer
body: These three examples have consistently been asked about in my classes when students first encounter the inflector, so I thought it would be nice to contribute these exceptions.

title: Use present? rather than empty in assert_template
body: options.present? is clearer than !options.empty? IMHO.

title: Increase readability of ternary statement in build method
body: Trying to grok the actionpack code, this line jarred a little, so moved the ternary statement up one line. All tests passing.

title: Typo Fix in AR CHANGELOG [ci skip]
symbolize_keys => symbolize_keys! on new hash; change sentence
body:
1. symbolize_keys => symbolize_keys! on new hash
2. Change "There're" => "There are" for better readability

title: Adding documentation to Renderer
body: I've added a bunch of comments so that hopefully the big picture of how the renderer works is a little bit clearer. In particular, I've added some documentation to the ``AbstractRenderer`` class which explains how the renderers that subclass it are used.

title: Postgresql array columns don't properly escape single quote strings when loading fixtures
body:
In the fixture builder there was a single statement that inserts the fixture row and yields something like:

    INSERT INTO table_name ("arr_column") VALUES ('{"asdf", "as'df"}')

The problem with this was that the single quote in the second array value needs to be escaped.  Normally they won't need to be escaped in strings, but when array columns go all the way to sql (instead of binding to the connection) they get wrapped in '{ and }' and that makes escaping them required.

This fix causes the insert to look more like:

    INSERT INTO table_name("arr_column") VALUES( $1 ) [ ["arr_column", ["asdf", "as''df"] ] ]

The extra single quote (') character is the escape for a single quote in a string. 

I made a test for this, to run the test:

    cd activerecord && ARCONN=postgresql ruby -Itest test/cases/adapters/postgresql/array_test.rb -n test_insert_fixture

To see the test fail revert the change at https://github.com/cconstantine/rails/commit/0e34a7efa6992e6771d34dc8163b79dd7df52667#L0R35

This change is only in postgresql code, and everything passes when I run 

    ARCONN=postgresql rake test_postgresql

This is a followup to the failed attempt to fix https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/10043 .

title: Avoid leak into controller's action_methods
body:
```ruby
class ExampleController < ActionController::Base
  layout -> { 'smth' }
end

ExampleController.action_methods
# => #<Set: {"_layout_from_proc"}>
```

title: Some revision on Working with JavaScript in Rails page.
body: This is my first pull request to Rails. I think I will get better. But, to start, I did some revision on "Working with JavaScript in Rails" documentation page.

title: Unify the format of returning nil
body:
In the rails source code, there are two cases when returning nil with "if" in one line.

* return nil if ...
* return if ...

They are the same meaning.
So I thought they should be unified.
I did grep, and I found that the latter case is major in the rails source code.
I replaced all of the former cases.

title: Use secure source for rubygems in engine tests
Fix subject-verb agreement in error msg (and other grammar stuff)
body:
Before: 
```
pending_migrations = [20130417223021]

> rake db:test:prepare
>> You have 1 pending migrations. 
```

After:
```
pending_migrations = [20130417223021]

> rake db:test:prepare
>> You have 1 pending migration. 
```

(And 2 other small grammatical errors.)

Note, I didn't see tests for these output messages. And for the pending migrations error, the only way I could think of to test it was to break it out into a separate method, which I didn't think was worth it. 

Feedback welcome.

(I also didn't think this warranted a changelog entry.)

title: Moved the check for the rails test environment into rails.rb
body:
This addresses issue #10238. The problem right now is that the ``ENV["RAILS_ENV"]`` variable only gets set to test when you do a ``require rails.all``. This is because the command that checks to see if the Rake tasks are performing tests are only defined there.

I've moved the code that checks for whether rake is running tests into the rails.rb file.

However, I'm stumped as to how to write a test for this. Any input would be welcome!

title: Refactoring increment and decrement in local cache
body: The increment and decrement commands are exactly same, so their logic is being refactored. I created a new method ``increment_or_decrement`` which carries out the logic of an increment or decrement.

title: Refactored the storage of a temporary version of the local cache.
body:
The two methods ``with_local_cache`` and ``bypass_local_cache`` basically do the same thing and save a temporary version of the local cache.

I've refactored this into its own method so that the code can be reused.

title: add :nodoc: mark to *Registry classes [ci skip]
Adding a local thread registry to store local caches.
body:
I've added a registry to store local caches. This should decrease the number of thread locals a lot because currently, every time you create a new local cache, you create a new thread local.

I'm using the ``PerThreadRegistry`` module to create a single registry object.

title: more descriptive error messages for class attributes
body: error messages now show the name of the invalid attribute

title: Using secure source https://rubygems.org when generating new plugin with Rails 3.2.13
body: Fixes https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/10245

title: Add `rails engine new <engine-name>` alias
body:
Alias for `rails plugin new <engine-name>`

Inspiration comes from @steveklabnik’s comment here:
https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/10233#issuecomment-16432249

title: Allow concerns defined as a string array
body:
Right now several of the route options (only, except) can be defined
as arrays of string or symbols. I was surprised when playing with
rails 4 and this didn't work for concerns.

- Added test for string array declaration.

With this change concerns could be declared with strings or symbols:

    resources :posts, concerns: [:commentable, :taggable]
    resources :media, concerns: %w(commentable taggable)

__This includes changes mentioned in an original pull request: https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/9725__

title: switch (and lazily convert) ivar names to 3.x
body: Fixes https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/9494

title: Reorganize MessageEncryptor
body: According to OpenSSL's documentation, cipher.random_iv must be called after cipher.encrypt and will set the returned IV on the cipher.

title: alias "rails plugin" to "rails plugin new"
body:
origin: #10229.

As we only have "rails plugin new" left it is convenient to alias it to "rails plugin". I tripped a few times myself only calling "rails plugin" and if "new" is the only argument left we can safely do the alias.

I think it is handy but I don't have a strong opinion about this one. If you feel like this is a bad change, just close.

title: ActiveSupport::TaggedLogger should tag each line of output
body:
```ruby
logger.tagged("REQUEST-XYZ") { logger.info "Hello\nWorld!" }
```

outputs

```
[REQUEST-XYZ] Hello
World!
```

It would be better to output

```
[REQUEST-XYZ] Hello
[REQUEST-XYZ] World!
```

Otherwise, in a distributed environment, you don't know which request generated the second line.
